result.execSummary:
The defendant Gregory M. Mashuda was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Caffee.  Victim notification complied with.  State moved to strike domestic abuse enhancer.  Defendant plead no contest to the amended charge.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the counts he plead to.    Defendant understood.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the pleas.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, and intelligently entered his pleas and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the pleas.  Found guilty of disorderly conduct, contrary to 947.01(1).  Joint recommendation for:  $50, plus costs.  Court ordered: $50.00, plus costs.  Total $516.00.  Pay today.
Per telephone request of Atty Caffee, FPT canceled and set for PLEAS.
Plea/sentencing hearing on August 1, 2016 at 01:30 pm.
At request of Atty. Mandy Caffee and ok'd with Michelle in DA's office, STC for 4/18/16 canceled and this matter set for jury trial.
Final pre-trial on July 11, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
Jury trial - 12 person on August 11, 2016 at 09:00 am.
from Attorney Caffee's office

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.    No violent, abusive, threatening or disorderly contact with: the victim, D.V.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person.  Attorney Caffee appeared by telephone.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties.  Defendant understood.  Defense waives reading of complaint.  Defendant entered NGP.  Court enters not guilty plea.  PTC 3/9 and STC 4/18 at 3 pm.  Attorney Caffee can appear by telephone at the STC.
